summary:
I've spend the majority of my career (over 10 years) developing software for XVR Simulation (formerly E-Semble BV). I spent most of my time working on the XVR On Scene product, which is VR training software to educate and train operational and tactical safety and security professionals. 

Creating XVR provided me and the rest of the team with some unique challenges.
For starters, with over 200 customers, training multiple disciplines of security professionals in over 8 languages, the software had to provide a high level of localization and customization. All these variations were built on the same code base, so we could provide our customers with regular updates. 
We could not simply discard the old software and start from scratch after each project; instead our core product has to be constantly refactored and improved.
Our customers spend a great deal of effort creating training scenarios, so the software also has to be backwards compatible, allowing those scenarios can be used in each new version.
Furthermore, the educators building the scenario often do not have an ICT background, and many of the trainees are not experienced gamers. Therefor the user interface must be powerful, yet simple and intuitive.

I worked on the systems which allowed the software to be used as an editor, with which people without a programming background could easily create their own scenarios. I also worked on creating a common code base from which localized and customized versions of the software could be quickly compiled.

I have also worked on automated testing, continuous integration and processing usage statistics.

projects.title: Game campaign: Falcon's First Flight
projects.description:
Falcon's First Flight is a campaign I made using the scenario editor of Star Wars Galactic Battlegrounds (using Age of Empires 2's Genie Engine).

I also made a mod which replaced some game assets. Furthermore, I created a listing of all the game assets to assist other modders.

The campaign was very well received by the community, and got very positive reviews (see the project page). To date the campaign has been downloaded 7786 times.

The joy I had building it, and the success, were the catalysts to pursuing a career in Game Development.

projects.title: CSI Serious Games
projects.description:
For the CSI Serious Games project, E-Semble and the Netherlands Forensic Institute jointly develop serious games for the purpose of forensic awareness training. The Forensic Awareness Games are an innovative combination of virtual reality technology and classic game methods used for example in board games such as Cluedo. 

CSI2
The objective of a Forensic Awareness Game is to introduce rescue professional players to forensic evidence and teach them the importance of protecting evidence during incident response actions. Rescue professionals of different fields can be trained with the game and are taught how to be part of the forensic chain. The game has found its use in the CSI Lab within the NFI Academy.

E-Semble is closely involved in the development and application of the board game elements as well as the virtual reality elements of the game for which several forensic scenarios are developed.

My key contribution to this project was creating the virtual clue cards, which can be edited by the end user.

projects.title: Serious Smoke & Fire
projects.description:
The Rook en Vuur (serious smoke and fire) project was initiated by the Dutch Safety Region of Utrecht, to develop more realistic smoke and fire for serious gaming exercises. Several serious gaming companies work together in this project to analyze the opportunities and to develop 
a prototype for the Security Region of Utrecht and the surrounding regions. The project is divided into two phases.

XVR Forest fire fighting9
The first phase is aimed at analyzing technologies to simulate smoke and flames very realistically. The results of the first phase are now being documented and the concept has been delivered to the Safety Region. The developed technology can be used to train fire fighting procedures for accidents in tunnels and to visualize the impact of the chosen procedures regarding smoke and fire emission.

The purpose of the second phase is to develop a simulator for wildfires, that can be used in realistic multidisciplinary exercises, with all actors involved in forest fire fighting. In this phase, adjacent regions of the Safety Region Utrecht are involved as well since they share responsibilities to combat fires in the national park De Hoge Veluwe.

My key contribution to this project was creating a movable fire line, to which the end user could add segments, allowing the fire front to stretch for miles. I also added water cannons to the student vehicle, and implemented logic which allowed the used to draw burned patches in the environment (trees would also change to a burned version of themselves).

After the first delivery of the project, I collaborated with Steven van Campen to design how the fire line could automatically progress through the forest.

profile_positions.description:
XVR Simulation (formerly E-Semble) develops simulation software - Serious Gaming - for the education, training and assessment of incident response and safety professionals, such as police, fire and medical services. 
XVR's mission is to increase the knowledge and expertise of these professionals resulting in a decrease of the number of victims and disasters. 

XVR Simulation’s prime product is the XVR Virtual Reality training software.
XVR has over 200 customers worldwide and is localized in more than 8 languages. 
With XVR, educators in the field of safety and security can create their own incidents to be used as training scenarios. They are also able to export their creations, and share them with their peers.
The software is set up as a subscription service, with customers receiving biannual updates, consisting of new content (3D environments and models) as well as usability improvements. In addition, the platform is also used for tailor-made projects. It has even been used as an examination system by both Rijkswaterstaat and NBBE (currently NIFV).

During my 10+ years at XVR I have worked on the XVR software product as a software developer. My work usually consist of some technical design (software architecture), followed by programming (initially in Quest3D, later in C#) and debugging. 

Besides programming on XVR, I have also done design and (automated) testing. I’m constantly on the lookout for ways to improve workflow and efficiency (by means of revised software architecture, tools and policy changes). I also created a lot of particle effects for our fire and smoke.

volunteer_experiences.description: During several weeks in the summers of 1992, 1993 and 1994 I volunteered at the YMCA of Aruba in San Nicolas. I worked as a counselor for the day camp, looking after a small groups kids in the age range 6-12. The kids would do activities at the YMCA building, and would also go out on excursions and swimming.

In the summer of 1995 I volunteered at StimAruba, an organisation which is involved with education and preservation of the environment and wildlife of Aruba. I worked as a counselor for their summer camp, looking after a small group of kids in the age range 8-13. The kids would visit wildlife reserves and museums, and learn about animals, plants, the history of Aruba and it's environment.

Although I care about a lot of causes (proper treatment of animals, environment, health, fair distribution of food and goods), I believe that most of these causes can only be effectively pursued if the country of focus has a stable, non-corrupt political environment. Freedom of speech and acceptance of human rights is a key prerequisite for this.
Therefore, I decided to sponsor Amnesty International as my charity of choice, many years ago. In 2012 they contacted me, and asked if I could help them raise funds, by going door to door. I did this in February 2012, and several years since, raising hundreds of euros.
